suggestionItems.description:
SuggestionItems are the items which are displayed in the suggestions list. The following properties can be used:
  • key - it is not displayed and may be used as internal technical field
  • text - it is displayed as normal suggestion text
  • icon
  • description - additional text that may be used to visually display search item type or category
suggestionItems.helpDescription:
SuggestionItems are the items which are displayed in the suggestions list. The following properties can be used:

  • text - it is displayed as normal suggestion text
  • icon
  • description - additional text that may be used to visually display search item type or category

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.f.cards.NumericHeader.description:
Displays general information in the header of the {@link sap.f.Card} and allows the configuration of a numeric value visualization. You can configure the title, subtitle, and status text, using the provided properties. To add more side number indicators, use the sideIndicators aggregation. Notes:
  • You should always set a title.
  • You should always have a maximum of two side indicators.
  • To show only basic information, use {@link sap.f.cards.Header Header} instead.
sap.f.cards.NumericHeader.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new NumericHeader. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getTitleMaxLines titleMaxLines} : int (default: 3)
    • {@link #getSubtitle subtitle} : string
    • {@link #getSubtitleMaxLines subtitleMaxLines} : int (default: 2)
    • {@link #getStatusText statusText} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconDisplayShape iconDisplayShape} : sap.m.AvatarShape (default: Circle)
    • {@link #getIconSrc iconSrc} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconInitials iconInitials} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconAlt iconAlt} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconBackgroundColor iconBackgroundColor} : sap.m.AvatarColor (default: Transparent)
    • {@link #getIconVisible iconVisible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getIconSize iconSize} : sap.m.AvatarSize (default: S)
    • {@link #getIconFitType iconFitType} : sap.m.AvatarImageFitType (default: Cover)
    • {@link #getUnitOfMeasurement unitOfMeasurement} : string
    • {@link #getNumber number} : string
    • {@link #getNumberSize numberSize} : string (default: "L")
    • {@link #getNumberVisible numberVisible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getScale scale} : string
    • {@link #getTrend trend} : sap.m.DeviationIndicator (default: "None")
    • {@link #getState state} : sap.m.ValueColor (default: "Neutral")
    • {@link #getDetails details} : string
    • {@link #getDetailsState detailsState} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
    • {@link #getDetailsMaxLines detailsMaxLines} : int (default: 1)
    • {@link #getSideIndicatorsAlignment sideIndicatorsAlignment} : sap.f.cards.NumericHeaderSideIndicatorsAlignment (default: "Begin")
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getSideIndicators sideIndicators} : sap.f.cards.NumericSideIndicator[]
    • {@link #getMicroChart microChart} : sap.ui.core.Control
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.f.cards.BaseHeader#constructor sap.f.cards.BaseHeader} can be used as well.
sap.f.cards.NumericHeader.helpDescription:
Displays general information in the header of the {@link sap.f.Card} and allows the configuration of a numeric value visualization. You can configure the title, subtitle, and status text, using the provided properties. To add more side number indicators, use the sideIndicators aggregation. Notes:
  • You should always set a title.
  • You should always have a maximum of two side indicators.
  • To show only basic information, use {@link sap.f.cards.Header Header} instead.

By default, the RETURN key without any modifier keys triggers validation, see {@link #triggerValidateFieldGroup}. Listen to this event to validate data of the controls belonging to a field group. See {@link #setFieldGroupIds}, or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

sap.f.name: sap.f
sap.f.description: SAPUI5 library with controls specialized for SAP Fiori apps.
sap.f.helpDescription: SAPUI5 library with controls specialized for SAP Fiori apps.

fieldHelpDisplay.description: Reference to the element to show the field help for this control; if unset, field help is show on the control itself.
fieldHelpDisplay.helpDescription: Reference to the element to show the field help for this control; if unset, field help is show on the control itself.

sap.f.ShellBar.description:
A horizontal bar control holding multiple child controls used as application shell header.

Overview

The ShellBar is used as the uppermost section (shell) of the app. It is fully responsive and adaptive, and corresponds to the SAP Fiori Design Guidelines.

Usage

Content specified in the ShellBar properties and aggregations is automatically positioned in dedicated places of the control.
sap.f.ShellBar.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ShellBar. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getSecondTitle secondTitle} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getHomeIcon homeIcon} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: "")
    • {@link #getHomeIconTooltip homeIconTooltip} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getShowMenuButton showMenuButton} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowNavButton showNavButton} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowCopilot showCopilot} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowSearch showSearch} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowNotifications showNotifications} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowProductSwitcher showProductSwitcher} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getNotificationsNumber notificationsNumber} : string (default: "")
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getMenu menu} : sap.m.Menu
    • {@link #getSearchManager searchManager} : sap.f.SearchManager
    • {@link #getProfile profile} : sap.m.Avatar
    • {@link #getAdditionalContent additionalContent} : sap.f.IShellBar[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:homeIconPressed homeIconPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:menuButtonPressed menuButtonPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:navButtonPressed navButtonPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:copilotPressed copilotPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:searchButtonPressed searchButtonPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:notificationsPressed notificationsPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:productSwitcherPressed productSwitcherPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:avatarPressed avatarPressed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.f.ShellBar.helpDescription:
A horizontal bar control holding multiple child controls used as application shell header.

Overview

The ShellBar is used as the uppermost section (shell) of the app. It is fully responsive and adaptive, and corresponds to the SAP Fiori Design Guidelines.

Usage

Content specified in the ShellBar properties and aggregations is automatically positioned in dedicated places of the control.

searchManager.helpDescription: Configurable search. Note: If showSearch is set to true, two search buttons appear.

additionalContent.description: Additional content to be displayed in the control. Note: Only controls implementing the {@link sap.f.IShellBar} interface are allowed.
additionalContent.helpDescription: Additional content to be displayed in the control. Note: Only controls implementing the {@link sap.f.IShellBar} interface are allowed.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.f.ProductSwitch.description: A layout control that provides specific configuration about how the items should be displayed.
sap.f.ProductSwitch.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ProductSwitch. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.f.ProductSwitchItem[]
  • Associations
    • {@link #getSelectedItem selectedItem} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.f.ProductSwitchItem)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.f.ProductSwitch.helpDescription: A layout control that provides specific configuration about how the items should be displayed.

See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

sap.f.cards.Header.description:
Displays general information in the header of the {@link sap.f.Card}. You can configure the title, subtitle, status text and icon, using the provided properties. Notes:
  • You should always set a title.
  • To show a KPI or any numeric information, use {@link sap.f.cards.NumericHeader} instead.
sap.f.cards.Header.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Header. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getTitleMaxLines titleMaxLines} : int (default: 3)
    • {@link #getSubtitle subtitle} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getSubtitleMaxLines subtitleMaxLines} : int (default: 2)
    • {@link #getStatusText statusText} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconDisplayShape iconDisplayShape} : sap.m.AvatarShape (default: Circle)
    • {@link #getIconSrc iconSrc} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconInitials iconInitials} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconAlt iconAlt} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getIconBackgroundColor iconBackgroundColor} : sap.m.AvatarColor (default: Transparent)
    • {@link #getIconVisible iconVisible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getIconSize iconSize} : sap.m.AvatarSize (default: S)
    • {@link #getIconFitType iconFitType} : sap.m.AvatarImageFitType (default: Cover)
    • {@link #getIconState iconState} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
  • Aggregations
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.f.cards.BaseHeader#constructor sap.f.cards.BaseHeader} can be used as well.
sap.f.cards.Header.helpDescription:
Displays general information in the header of the {@link sap.f.Card}. You can configure the title, subtitle, status text and icon, using the provided properties. Notes:
  • You should always set a title.
  • To show a KPI or any numeric information, use {@link sap.f.cards.NumericHeader} instead.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

This class does not have its own settings, but all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticButton#constructor sap.m.semantic.SemanticButton} can be used.
sap.f.semantic.SemanticButton.helpDescription: A base class for the available semantic actions, such as {@link sap.f.semantic.AddAction AddAction}, {@link sap.f.semantic.CloseAction CloseAction}, etc.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.f.GridListItem.description: The GridListItem with a content aggregation can be used to display all kind of information. It is used in {@link sap.f.GridList sap.f.GridList}. Note: Even though the content aggregation can be used for any control, complex responsive layout controls, such as Table, Form, etc, should not be aggregated as content.
sap.f.GridListItem.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new GridListItem. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.ListItemBase#constructor sap.m.ListItemBase} can be used as well.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

highlightText.helpDescription: Defines the semantics of the {@link sap.m.ListItemBase#setHighlight highlight} property for accessibility purposes.

metadataContexts.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected. The special setting is only for internal use.

highlight.description: Defines the highlight state of the list items. Valid values for the highlight property are values of the enumerations {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType} or {@link sap.ui.core.IndicationColor} (only values of Indication01 to Indication10 are supported for accessibility contrast reasons). Accessibility support is provided through the associated {@link sap.m.ListItemBase#setHighlightText highlightText} property. If the highlight property is set to a value of {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType}, the highlightText property does not need to be set because a default text is used. However, the default text can be overridden by setting the highlightText property. In all other cases the highlightText property must be set.
highlight.helpDescription: Defines the highlight state of the list items. Valid values for the highlight property are values of the enumerations {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType} or {@link sap.ui.core.IndicationColor} (only values of Indication01 to Indication10 are supported for accessibility contrast reasons). Accessibility support is provided through the associated {@link sap.m.ListItemBase#setHighlightText highlightText} property. If the highlight property is set to a value of {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType}, the highlightText property does not need to be set because a default text is used. However, the default text can be overridden by setting the highlightText property. In all other cases the highlightText property must be set.

sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutData.description: Holds layout data for sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout. Allows LayoutData of type sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop or sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutFlexibleColumnLayoutDataForTablet
sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutData.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutData. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getDesktopLayoutData desktopLayoutData} : sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop
    • {@link #getTabletLayoutData tabletLayoutData} : sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForTablet
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.LayoutData#constructor sap.ui.core.LayoutData} can be used as well.
sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutData.helpDescription: Holds layout data for sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout. Allows LayoutData of type sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop or sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutFlexibleColumnLayoutDataForTablet

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isResize: type: boolean, description: Indicates whether the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once changed due to resize of the entire browser window
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.maxColumnsCo:
type: int, description: The maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once based on the available screen size and control settings.
    Possible values are:
  • 3 for browser size of 1280px or more
  • 2 for browser size between 960px and 1280px
  • 1 for browser size less than 960px

stateChange.name: stateChange
stateChange.description:
Fired when there is a change in the layout property or in the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once.

    The interactions that may lead to a state change are:
  • The property layout was changed indirectly by the user dragging the column separator or clicking on its arrow (where arrow is available).
  • The user resized the browser window beyond a breakpoint, thus changing the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once.


Note: The event is suppressed while the control has zero width and will be fired the first time it gets a non-zero width
stateChange.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

sap.f.DynamicPageTitle.description:
Title of the {@link sap.f.DynamicPage}.

Overview

The DynamicPageTitle control is part of the {@link sap.f.DynamicPage} family and is used to serve as title of the {@link sap.f.DynamicPage DynamicPage}.

Usage

The DynamicPageTitle can hold any control and displays the most important information regarding the object that will always remain visible while scrolling. Note: The actions aggregation accepts any UI5 control, but it`s recommended to use controls, suitable for {@link sap.m.Toolbar} and {@link sap.m.OverflowToolbar}. If the toggleHeaderOnTitleClick property of the {@link sap.f.DynamicPage DynamicPage} is set to true, the user can switch between the expanded/collapsed states of the {@link sap.f.DynamicPageHeader DynamicPageHeader} by clicking on the DynamicPageTitle or by using the expand/collapse visual indicators, positioned at the bottom of the DynamicPageTitle and the DynamicPageHeader. If set to false, the DynamicPageTitle is not clickable, the visual indicators are not available, and the app must provide other means for expanding/collapsing the DynamicPageHeader, if necessary.

Responsive Behavior

The responsive behavior of the DynamicPageTitle depends on the behavior of the content that is displayed.
sap.f.DynamicPageTitle.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new DynamicPageTitle. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getPrimaryArea primaryArea} : sap.f.DynamicPageTitleArea (default: Begin)
    • {@link #getAreaShrinkRatio areaShrinkRatio} : sap.f.DynamicPageTitleShrinkRatio (default: "1:1.6:1.6")
    • {@link #getBackgroundDesign backgroundDesign} : sap.m.BackgroundDesign
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getHeading heading} : sap.ui.core.Control
    • {@link #getSnappedHeading snappedHeading} : sap.ui.core.Control
    • {@link #getExpandedHeading expandedHeading} : sap.ui.core.Control
    • {@link #getActions actions} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getNavigationActions navigationActions} : sap.m.Button[]
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getSnappedContent snappedContent} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getExpandedContent expandedContent} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getSnappedTitleOnMobile snappedTitleOnMobile} : sap.m.Title
    • {@link #getBreadcrumbs breadcrumbs} : sap.m.IBreadcrumbs
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:stateChange stateChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

Title of the {@link sap.f.DynamicPage}.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

navigationActions.description:
The DynamicPageTitle navigation actions. Notes:
  • The navigationActions position depends on the control size. If the control size is 1280px or bigger, they are rendered right next to the actions. Otherwise, they are rendered in the top-right area, above the actions. If a large number of elements(buttons) are used, there could be visual degradations as the space for the navigationActions is limited.
  • If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.
navigationActions.helpDescription:
The DynamicPageTitle navigation actions. Notes:
  • The navigationActions position depends on the control size. If the control size is 1280px or bigger, they are rendered right next to the actions. Otherwise, they are rendered in the top-right area, above the actions. If a large number of elements(buttons) are used, there could be visual degradations as the space for the navigationActions is limited.
  • If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.

snappedTitleOnMobile.description: The only content that is displayed in the DynamicPageTitle when it is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in collapsed (snapped) state. Using this aggregation enables you to provide a simple, single-line title that takes less space on the smaller phone screens when the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state. Note: The content set in this aggregation overrides all the other DynamicPageTitle aggregations and is only visible on phone mobile devices in collapsed (snapped) state of the DynamicPageHeader.
snappedTitleOnMobile.helpDescription: The only content that is displayed in the DynamicPageTitle when it is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in collapsed (snapped) state. Using this aggregation enables you to provide a simple, single-line title that takes less space on the smaller phone screens when the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state. Note: The content set in this aggregation overrides all the other DynamicPageTitle aggregations and is only visible on phone mobile devices in collapsed (snapped) state of the DynamicPageHeader.

expandedContent.description: The content that is displayed in the DynamicPageTitle in expanded state.
expandedContent.helpDescription: The content that is displayed in the DynamicPageTitle in expanded state.

heading.description:
The heading is positioned in the DynamicPageTitle left area and is displayed in both expanded and collapsed (snapped) states of the header. Use this aggregation to display a title (or any other UI5 control that serves as a heading) that has to be present in both expanded and collapsed states of the header. Notes:
  • heading is mutually exclusive with snappedHeading and expandedHeading. If heading is provided, both snappedHeading and expandedHeading are ignored. heading is useful when the content of snappedHeading and expandedHeading needs to be the same as it replaces them both.
  • If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.
heading.helpDescription:
The heading is positioned in the DynamicPageTitle left area and is displayed in both expanded and collapsed (snapped) states of the header. Use this aggregation to display a title (or any other UI5 control that serves as a heading) that has to be present in both expanded and collapsed states of the header. Notes:
  • heading is mutually exclusive with snappedHeading and expandedHeading. If heading is provided, both snappedHeading and expandedHeading are ignored. heading is useful when the content of snappedHeading and expandedHeading needs to be the same as it replaces them both.
  • If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.

snappedContent.description: The content that is displayed in the DynamicPageTitle in collapsed (snapped) state. Note: If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.
snappedContent.helpDescription: The content that is displayed in the DynamicPageTitle in collapsed (snapped) state. Note: If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

expandedHeading.description: The expandedHeading is positioned in the DynamicPageTitle left area and is displayed when the header is in expanded state only. Use this aggregation to display a title (or any other UI5 control that serves as a heading) that has to be present in expanded state only. Note: In order for expandedHeading to be taken into account, heading has to be empty. Combine expandedHeading with snappedHeading to switch content when the header switches state.
expandedHeading.helpDescription: The expandedHeading is positioned in the DynamicPageTitle left area and is displayed when the header is in expanded state only. Use this aggregation to display a title (or any other UI5 control that serves as a heading) that has to be present in expanded state only. actions.description:
The DynamicPageTitle actions.
Note: The actions aggregation accepts any UI5 control. However, it is best to use buttons or controls that work well inside toolbars, such as those typically used with {@link sap.m.Toolbar} and {@link sap.m.OverflowToolbar}. Note: If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.

snappedHeading.description:

  • If the snappedTitleOnMobile aggregation is set, its content overrides this aggregation when the control is viewed on a phone mobile device and the DynamicPageHeader is in its collapsed (snapped) state.

visible.description: Whether the control should be visible on the screen. If set to false, a placeholder will be rendered to mark the location of the invisible control in the DOM of the current page. The placeholder will be hidden and have zero dimensions (display: none). Also see {@link module:sap/ui/core/InvisibleRenderer InvisibleRenderer}.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.
busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. primaryArea.description:
Deprecated! Since 1.54 Please use the areaShrinkRatio property instead. The value of areaShrinkRatio must be set in Heading:Content:Actions format where Heading, Content and Actions are numbers greater than or equal to 0. The greater value a section has the faster it shrinks when the screen size is being reduced. primaryArea=Begin can be achieved by setting a low number for the Heading area to areaShrinkRatio, for example 1:1.6:1.6. primaryArea=Middle can be achieved by setting a low number for the Content area to areaShrinkRatio, for example 1.6:1:1.6.
Determines which of the DynamicPageTitle areas (Begin, Middle) is primary. Note: The primary area is shrinking at lower rate, remaining visible as much as it can.
primaryArea.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.54 Please use the areaShrinkRatio property instead. fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is fired. For backward compatibility with older releases, field group IDs are syntactically not limited, but it is suggested to use only valid {@link sap.ui.core.ID}s. See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.
fieldGroupIds.helpDescription: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is fired. For backward compatibility with older releases, field group IDs are syntactically not limited, but it is suggested to use only valid {@link sap.ui.core.ID}s. See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

areaShrinkRatio.description: Assigns shrinking ratio to the DynamicPageTitle areas (Heading, Content, Actions). The greater value a section has the faster it shrinks when the screen size is being reduced. The value must be set in Heading:Content:Actions format where Title, Content and Actions are numbers greater than or equal to 0. If set to 0, the respective area will not shrink. For example, if 2:7:1 is set, the Content area will shrink seven times faster than the Actions area. So, when all three areas have width of 500px and the available space is reduced by 100px the Title area will reduced by 20px, the Content area - by 70px and the Actions area - by 10px. If all the areas have assigned values greater than 1, the numbers are scaled so that at least one of them is equal to 1. For example, value of 2:4:8 is equal to 1:2:4. When this property is set the primaryArea property has no effect.
areaShrinkRatio.helpDescription: Assigns shrinking ratio to the DynamicPageTitle areas (Heading, Content, Actions). The greater value a section has the faster it shrinks when the screen size is being reduced. The value must be set in Heading:Content:Actions format where Title, Content and Actions are numbers greater than or equal to 0. If set to 0, the respective area will not shrink. For example, if 2:7:1 is set, the Content area will shrink seven times faster than the Actions area. So, when all three areas have width of 500px and the available space is reduced by 100px the Title area will reduced by 20px, the Content area - by 70px and the Actions area - by 10px. If all the areas have assigned values greater than 1, the numbers are scaled so that at least one of them is equal to 1. For example, value of 2:4:8 is equal to 1:2:4. When this property is set the primaryArea property has no effect.

sap.f.GridContainerItemLayoutData.description: Holds layout data for an item inside a sap.f.GridContainer.
sap.f.GridContainerItemLayoutData.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.f.GridContainerItemLayoutData. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getColumns columns} : int (default: 1)
    • {@link #getMinRows minRows} : int
    • {@link #getRows rows} : int

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

minRows.description: Specifies the minimum number of rows, which the item should take.
minRows.helpDescription: Specifies the minimum number of rows, which the item should take.

objectBindings.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

columns.description: Specifies the number of columns, which the item should take Note: Make sure that the item does not have more columns than the total columns in the grid. Use {@link sap.f.GridContainer#attachLayoutChange} or a resize listener to handle when columns count is changed for the grid. If item has more columns at some point, they will be automatically reduced to the total grid columns. This is done to prevent broken layout (grid blowout) that affects all items.

sap.f.routing.Router.description:
The sap.f.routing.Router extends the capabilities of the standard {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Router} to support flexible and responsive layouts based on {@link sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout} as the root control. This router enables advanced navigation scenarios tailored to flexible column layouts, such as changing both the layout type (e.g., OneColumn, TwoColumnsMidExpanded) and the currently displayed views within individual columns. Compared to {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Router}, it adds support for additional target properties:
  • level: Defines the hierarchical level of the target view for proper history and back navigation handling
  • transition: Specifies the type of transition animation between views (e.g., slide, fade)
  • transitionParameters: Custom parameters for transitions
Compared to {@link sap.m.routing.Router}, it further introduces a layout property on each route, allowing you to define the desired {@link sap.f.LayoutType} to be applied to the FlexibleColumnLayout root control during navigation. See {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Router} for the constructor arguments.
sap.f.routing.Router.helpDescription:
The sap.f.routing.Router extends the capabilities of the standard {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Router} to support flexible and responsive layouts based on {@link sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout} as the root control. This router enables advanced navigation scenarios tailored to flexible column layouts, such as changing both the layout type (e.g., OneColumn, TwoColumnsMidExpanded) and the currently displayed views within individual columns. Compared to {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Router}, it adds support for additional target properties:
  • level: Defines the hierarchical level of the target view for proper history and back navigation handling
  • transition: Specifies the type of transition animation between views (e.g., slide, fade)
  • transitionParameters: Custom parameters for transitions
Compared to {@link sap.m.routing.Router}, it further introduces a layout property on each route, allowing you to define the desired {@link sap.f.LayoutType} to be applied to the FlexibleColumnLayout root control during navigation. See {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Router} for the constructor arguments.

sap.f.DynamicPageAccessibleLandmarkInfo.description: Settings for accessible landmarks which can be applied to the container elements of a sap.f.DynamicPage control. These landmarks are used by assistive technologies (such as screen readers) to provide a meaningful page overview.
sap.f.DynamicPageAccessibleLandmarkInfo.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.f.DynamicPageAccessibleLandmarkInfo element. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getRootRole rootRole} : sap.ui.core.AccessibleLandmarkRole (default: "None")
    • {@link #getRootLabel rootLabel} : string
    • {@link #getContentRole contentRole} : sap.ui.core.AccessibleLandmarkRole (default: "None")
    • {@link #getContentLabel contentLabel} : string
    • {@link #getHeaderRole headerRole} : sap.ui.core.AccessibleLandmarkRole (default: "None")
    • {@link #getHeaderLabel headerLabel} : string
    • {@link #getFooterRole footerRole} : sap.ui.core.AccessibleLandmarkRole (default: "None")
    • {@link #getFooterLabel footerLabel} : string
    • {@link #getHeaderContentLabel headerContentLabel} : string
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.f.DynamicPageAccessibleLandmarkInfo.helpDescription: Settings for accessible landmarks which can be applied to the container elements of a sap.f.DynamicPage control. These landmarks are used by assistive technologies (such as screen readers) to provide a meaningful page overview.

sap.f.routing.TargetHandler.description: Used for closing dialogs and showing transitions in NavContainers when targets are displayed. Note: You should not create an own instance of this class. It is created when using {@link sap.f.routing.Router} or {@link sap.f.routing.Targets}. Note: You may use the {@link #setCloseDialogs} function to specify if dialogs should be closed on displaying other views. The dialogs are closed when a different target is displayed than the previously displayed one, otherwise the dialogs are kept open.
sap.f.routing.TargetHandler.helpDescription: Used for closing dialogs and showing transitions in NavContainers when targets are displayed. Note: You should not create an own instance of this class. It is created when using {@link sap.f.routing.Router} or {@link sap.f.routing.Targets}. Note: You may use the {@link #setCloseDialogs} function to specify if dialogs should be closed on displaying other views. The dialogs are closed when a different target is displayed than the previously displayed one, otherwise the dialogs are kept open.

sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop.description: Holds layout data for columns of sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout on desktop.
sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTwoColumnsBeginExpanded twoColumnsBeginExpanded} : string (default: "67/33/0")
    • {@link #getTwoColumnsMidExpanded twoColumnsMidExpanded} : string (default: "33/67/0")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsBeginExpandedEndHidden threeColumnsBeginExpandedEndHidden} : string (default: "67/33/0")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsEndExpanded threeColumnsEndExpanded} : string (default: "25/25/50")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsMidExpanded threeColumnsMidExpanded} : string (default: "25/50/25")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsMidExpandedEndHidden threeColumnsMidExpandedEndHidden} : string (default: "33/67/0")
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.LayoutData#constructor sap.ui.core.LayoutData} can be used as well.
sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForDesktop.helpDescription: Holds layout data for columns of sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout on desktop.

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.layout: type: sap.f.LayoutType, description: The value of the layout property
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isNavigation: type: boolean, description: Indicates whether the layout changed as a result of the user clicking a column separator's arrow or dragging the column separators
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isResize: type: boolean, description: Indicates whether the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once changed due to resize of the entire browser window
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.maxColumnsCo:
type: int, description: The maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once based on the available screen size and control settings.
    Possible values are:
  • 3 for browser size of 1280px or more
  • 2 for browser size between 960px and 1280px
  • 1 for browser size less than 960px

stateChange.name: stateChange
stateChange.description:
Fired when there is a change in the layout property or in the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once.

    The interactions that may lead to a state change are:
  • The property layout was changed indirectly by the user dragging the column separator or clicking on its arrow (where arrow is available).
  • The user resized the browser window beyond a breakpoint, thus changing the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once.


Note: The event is suppressed while the control has zero width and will be fired the first time it gets a non-zero width
stateChange.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

For example, these landmarks are used by assistive technologies (such as screen readers) to provide a meaningful columns overview.
sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutAccessibleLand.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutAccessibleLandmarkInfo element. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getFirstColumnLabel firstColumnLabel} : string
    • {@link #getMiddleColumnLabel middleColumnLabel} : string
    • {@link #getLastColumnLabel lastColumnLabel} : string
    • {@link #getFirstColumnBackArrowLabel firstColumnBackArrowLabel} : string
    • {@link #getMiddleColumnForwardArrowLabel middleColumnForwardArrowLabel} : string
    • {@link #getMiddleColumnBackArrowLabel middleColumnBackArrowLabel} : string
    • {@link #getLastColumnForwardArrowLabel lastColumnForwardArrowLabel} : string
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.

eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.layout: type: sap.f.LayoutType, description: The value of the layout property
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isNavigation: type: boolean, description: Indicates whether the layout changed as a result of the user clicking a column separator's arrow or dragging the column separators
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isResize: type: boolean, description: Indicates whether the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once changed due to resize of the entire browser window
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.maxColumnsCo:
type: int, description: The maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once based on the available screen size and control settings.
    Possible values are:
  • 3 for browser size of 1280px or more
  • 2 for browser size between 960px and 1280px
  • 1 for browser size less than 960px

stateChange.name: stateChange
stateChange.description:
Fired when there is a change in the layout property or in the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once.

    The interactions that may lead to a state change are:
  • The property layout was changed indirectly by the user dragging the column separator or clicking on its arrow (where arrow is available).
  • The user resized the browser window beyond a breakpoint, thus changing the maximum number of columns that can be displayed at once.


Note: The event is suppressed while the control has zero width and will be fired the first time it gets a non-zero width
stateChange.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

modelContextChange.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

sap.f.cards.CardBadgeCustomData.description: Contains a single key/value pair of custom data attached to an Element. For more information, see {@link sap.ui.core.Element#data Element.prototype.data} and {@link topic:91f0c3ee6f4d1014b6dd926db0e91070 Custom Data - Attaching Data Objects to Controls}.
sap.f.cards.CardBadgeCustomData.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new CardBadgeCustomData element. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getVisibilityMode visibilityMode} : sap.f.CardBadgeVisibilityMode (default: Disappear)
    • {@link #getState state} : string (default: IndicationColor.Indication05)
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAnnouncementText announcementText} : string (default: "")
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.CustomData#constructor sap.ui.core.CustomData} can be used as well.
sap.f.cards.CardBadgeCustomData.helpDescription: Contains a single key/value pair of custom data attached to an Element. For more information, see {@link sap.ui.core.Element#data Element.prototype.data} and {@link topic:91f0c3ee6f4d1014b6dd926db0e91070 Custom Data - Attaching Data Objects to Controls}.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

id.description: Unique ID of this instance. If not given, a so called autoID will be generated by the framework. AutoIDs use a unique prefix that must not be used for Ids that the application (or other code) creates. It can be configured option 'autoIDPrefix', see {@link topic:91f2d03b6f4d1014b6dd926db0e91070 Configuration Options and URL Parameters}.

value.description: The data stored in this CustomData object. When the data is just stored, it can be any JS type, but when it is to be written to HTML (writeToDom == true) then it must be a string. If this restriction is violated, a warning will be logged and nothing will be written to the DOM.
value.helpDescription: The data stored in this CustomData object. When the data is just stored, it can be any JS type, but when it is to be written to HTML (writeToDom == true) then it must be a string. If this restriction is violated, a warning will be logged and nothing will be written to the DOM.

key.description: The key of the data in this CustomData object. When the data is just stored, it can be any string, but when it is to be written to HTML (writeToDom == true) then it must also be a valid HTML attribute name. It must conform to the {@link sap.ui.core.ID} type and may contain no colon. To avoid collisions, it also may not start with "sap-ui". When written to HTML, the key is prefixed with "data-". If any restriction is violated, a warning will be logged and nothing will be written to the DOM.
key.helpDescription: The key of the data in this CustomData object. When the data is just stored, it can be any string, but when it is to be written to HTML (writeToDom == true) then it must also be a valid HTML attribute name. It must conform to the {@link sap.ui.core.ID} type and may contain no colon. To avoid collisions, it also may not start with "sap-ui". When written to HTML, the key is prefixed with "data-". If any restriction is violated, a warning will be logged and nothing will be written to the DOM.

writeToDom.description:
If set to "true" and the value is of type "string" and the key conforms to the documented restrictions, this custom data is written to the HTML root element of the control as a "data-*" attribute. If the key is "abc" and the value is "cde", the HTML will look as follows: 
  <SomeTag ... data-abc="cde" ... >
Thus the application can provide stable attributes by data binding which can be used for styling or identification purposes. ATTENTION: use carefully to not create huge attributes or a large number of them.
writeToDom.helpDescription:
If set to "true" and the value is of type "string" and the key conforms to the documented restrictions, this custom data is written to the HTML root element of the control as a "data-*" attribute. If the key is "abc" and the value is "cde", the HTML will look as follows: 
  <SomeTag ... data-abc="cde" ... >
Thus the application can provide stable attributes by data binding which can be used for styling or identification purposes. ATTENTION: use carefully to not create huge attributes or a large number of them.

Constructor for a new sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayoutDataForTablet. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTwoColumnsBeginExpanded twoColumnsBeginExpanded} : string (default: "67/33/0")
    • {@link #getTwoColumnsMidExpanded twoColumnsMidExpanded} : string (default: "33/67/0")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsBeginExpandedEndHidden threeColumnsBeginExpandedEndHidden} : string (default: "67/33/0")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsEndExpanded threeColumnsEndExpanded} : string (default: "0/33/67")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsMidExpanded threeColumnsMidExpanded} : string (default: "0/67/33")
    • {@link #getThreeColumnsMidExpandedEndHidden threeColumnsMidExpandedEndHidden} : string (default: "33/67/0")
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.LayoutData#constructor sap.ui.core.LayoutData} can be used as well.

sap.f.semantic.CloseAction.description: A semantic-specific button, eligible for the closeAction aggregation of the {@link sap.f.semantic.SemanticPage} to be placed in its title.
sap.f.semantic.CloseAction.constructorDescription: Constructor for a new CloseAction. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object. This class does not have its own settings, but all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.f.semantic.SemanticButton#constructor sap.f.semantic.SemanticButton} can be used.
sap.f.semantic.CloseAction.helpDescription: A semantic-specific button, eligible for the closeAction aggregation of the {@link sap.f.semantic.SemanticPage} to be placed in its title.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.f.routing.Targets.description: Provides a convenient way for placing views into the correct containers of your app. The sap.f extension of Targets also handles the triggering of page navigation when the target control is an {@link sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout}. Other controls are also allowed, but the extra parameters level, transition, and transitionParameters are ignored and it behaves as {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Targets}. When a target is displayed, dialogs are being closed. To change this, use {@link #getTargetHandler} and {@link sap.f.routing.TargetHandler#setCloseDialogs}.
sap.f.routing.Targets.helpDescription: Provides a convenient way for placing views into the correct containers of your app. The sap.f extension of Targets also handles the triggering of page navigation when the target control is an {@link sap.f.FlexibleColumnLayout}. Other controls are also allowed, but the extra parameters level, transition, and transitionParameters are ignored and it behaves as {@link sap.ui.core.routing.Targets}. When a target is displayed, dialogs are being closed. To change this, use {@link #getTargetHandler} and {@link sap.f.routing.TargetHandler#setCloseDialogs}.

sap.f.semantic.PositiveAction.description: A semantic-specific button, eligible for the positiveAction aggregation of the {@link sap.f.semantic.SemanticPage} to be placed in its footer.
sap.f.semantic.PositiveAction.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new PositiveAction. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getText text} : string
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.f.semantic.SemanticButton#constructor sap.f.semantic.SemanticButton} can be used as well.
sap.f.semantic.PositiveAction.helpDescription: A semantic-specific button, eligible for the positiveAction aggregation of the {@link sap.f.semantic.SemanticPage} to be placed in its footer.
